(You don't have to wait until then, either, because Imani and all of the other countless incredible Black disabled people can also weigh in on all your upcoming discussions right now.)

replies.author: @LynetteA68
replies.text:
I just watched an episode of Piers Morgan (yuck) and he had a panel on talking about pride month etc! Of course as Piers & other right wingers do they make sure the ANTI pride month person is a straight black guy who‚Äôs there to complain about pride month! He said if there‚Äôs a gay pride month then he wants a ‚ÄúSTRAIGHT‚Äù pride month! NEXT they‚Äôll be complaining about Disability pride month & they‚Äôll start demanding they get an ablest pride month!! It‚Äôs astounding they don‚Äôt realize that EVERY month is already literally by default STRAIGHT ABLEIST pride month!! Unfortunately the right wing üëøhas their whole messaging/messenger thing figured out & it‚Äôs SCARY!! If you read RepubliCON Project 2025 and you‚Äôre not chilled to your core idk what to tell ya!! As a Native American nothing scares me more than right wing Trumpturd politicians & Trumpturd supporters/voters & their plans for America!! 

Achukma Hullo
(‚úåüèºü´∂üèºin Choctaw language) üòä

author: @trm5280
text: Imani's story about using her crutch to pull the trash is the kind of innovation born of adversity. My mother uses a crutch & has had to figure out different ways to do things too. The racists think the diversity in DEI is all about race, but working in IT, I've seen that people with disabilities are some of the most valuable contributors because their perspectives really help drive inclusiveness in innovation for developing new products and tech.

replies.author: @RowenaSnow-px3jg

author: @Samwyze
text: This was a great eye opening conversation, thank you. My mom has multiple sclerosis, and is wheelchair bound. Don't get down on yourself, you may not read music or a foreign language, but you know legalese. That's a feat in itself.

author: @emisformaker
text:
I saw Imani and I clicked. Without her advocacy on Twitter, I wouldn't now know that I'm autistic (it was a convoluted path, but it happened). The work to dismantle ableism, internally and externally, continues, but in the meantime I've been able to offer myself and others more empathy due to the advocacy of Imani and others in the disability justice space online.
Sidenote: Autism is strongly genetic, and a common mis-diagnosis or co-diagnosis for low-support needs autistic women is borderline personality disorder. I had a BPD diagnosis for years before I understood I'm autistic, and I'm still teasing apart whether BPD even fits into that understanding at all.

replies.author: @RowenaSnow-px3jg
replies.text: @emisformaker¬† Dr Tony Attwood is an autism expert. He says the way people react to autism discrimination and bullying may produce SYMPTOMS that look like BPD without necessarily being BPD.

author: @withainsley

But I have expressed the same  sentiment about Olay regularly.

author: @neopets666

author: @LexyconDevil
text:
I love Imani and following her on Twitter. I've been chronically ill with endometriosis as well as 51/50'd--it's crazy what people don't know if they haven't been institutionalized or seen the systemic errors of the medical system.

On average it takes 10 years to get diagnosed with endometriosis--I was "lucky" and it took 4 years at least, five at most.
My GPs gave me the run around until one day my birth control implant mainly there to stop my period (their only treatment for Endo so far is to stop your period from making it worse)--I menstruated for about a month or more and was literally told I had to wait a month to see someone about taking it out. "You have to wait it out" they said, as if it hadn't been working fine until post COVID with pandemic stresses during work. I had to quit my job.

Finally I get a laproscopy. Finally I learn you get implants before you get scar tissue; endometriosis is when your endometrium has ended up outside of your uterus, which they call an implant.
During the laproscopy the surgeon can burn off any scar tissue... They did nothing about that implant, without any good explanation.

It took another three to four years to see not a gynocologist but a Urogynocoligist to find out it's been my pelvic floor giving me an absolute world of pain. Birth control helps with extreme symptoms like nausea and feeling menstrual outside of PMS and menstruation (truly hell on earth) but I still had very persistent pelvic pain. Not abdominal, but I've had my stomach checked so many times they decided to check on my peeing.

I now know the urogynocoligist knows about the pelvic floor because they're concerned about you passing waist; the gyno couldn't tell me jack or shit about anything because they not only mostly deal with pregnant woman but pregnancy related conditions--they don't have as much expertise about reproductive issues like PMDD or anything unrelated to being pregnant. The urogyno had experience because that's where you get asked if your uterus is falling out--they deal with people who are having trouble.

I just had to rant because it's such bullshit how doctors can speak to you like they know better than a person repeatedly telling them a lot of endometriosis tells and that they're in daily pain. They suck with pain but in general the GPs kinda are almost there to block the door to specialists who know what they're talking about by eliminating all of their possiblities--problem is, this isn't done within a few appointments, it's done with a lot of reminding them WHAT YOUR ISSUE HAS BEEN over the course of monthly visits.

I kinda think a lot of doctors especially GPs were never taught bedside manner because it doesn't exist for certain people.

replies.author: @LexyconDevil
replies.text:
Do you think any doctors went to look up the symptoms for Endo, which absolutely include digestive issues and nausea?!

No. I don't know what they do but none came prepared the next time with different theories or ideas. Just lifestyle changes, blood tests, change your medication, you would hate a laproscopy and I'm only going to say that as early as possible

I don't remember the GPs mentioning a laproscopy but if they did they made it sound like an invasive surgery with a long recovery time just by their tone. I had to be told by a gyno about the laproscopy, not the GPs who kept sending me to get ultrasounds...

Fun fact. Ultrasounds at best can find cysts. You NEED surgery to see Endo because it doesn't show up on current scanners.

author: @carolkoski4875
text: Found your channel through Jarvis' video, and this interview is so real and important. Genuinely a public resource for a topic that everyone should know more about. Listening to the experiences of two disabled black women being one was well made me feel more secure in my beliefs and it reasonated with me a lot. Keep up the good work, the both of you! The part about how language affects black people more is sooo true, I know more than one black women who refuse accomodations and make their own lives harder so they don't have to "look" disabled.

author: @madeupname3008
text: 18:04 the inacessability of public spaces also in regards to covid (no precautions being taken anywhere) means disabled people are effectively forced to stay out of public still unless you're willing to risk your life. Thats so messed up

author: @samf8405
text:
This was such a fantastic conversation! I am 24 and have no access to healthcare to legally prove I'm disabled (nor can I get a job because the only places that get back to me are the jobs I physically can't do), my mom is disabled and homeless and is discriminated against in so many ways because of both of those things, and one of my best friend's moms who was disabled recently passed away due to medical neglect resulting sepsis.

It's unbelievable the level of discrimination disabled folks face on a daily basis and the way abled folks are willing to turn a blind eye, and equally unbelievable is the level of cognitive dissonance able-bodied folks have towards their own relationship to disability. Like you both stated, we'll all be disabled at some point in our lives, and yet we shy away from that language, believing claiming it will be a curse upon us rather than a reason to accommodate and that is absolutely because of our unhealthy relationship to work that has been perpetuated by the patriarchy, the church, and capitalists.

I always love hearing people discuss disability rights, even though the conversation itself revolves around so many difficult, sad, and genuinely infuriating topics. Thank you both for shedding further light on these issues and providing a space to talk about them üåª

I was raised RC and was constantly told my faith wasn't strong enough, sick is sin, and God was mad at me. This started in kindergarten. It's amazing how people who accomplish less with so much more judge the disabled. 
Healthy people need to realize you can be disabled in a heartbeat, especially now with the Pandemic. 

So grateful for Imani - Goddess Avocateüíôüíúüíó
We don't have lawyers for disability like other minority  groups. We need a Marc Elias!

author: @ObiWanStromb0li

author: @FullElvenCosplay
text:
Thank you for doing this talk! The way I had to be an adult to get diagnosed with Autism, because as AFAB biracial person in the Midwest, I was diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder with Oppositional Defiant Disorder and medicated as such with sedatives and SSRIs through my teens...only for all of those "symptoms" to disappear when I moved out of the situation I was in and began life on my own. I had other things present as I was able to fully become myself and having an Autistic kid they wanted to test my other kids and I thought to get tested myself. Suddenly EVERYTHING made sense. 

I had no idea though that racism in mental health systems meant BIPOC folk were far more likely to be given behavioral disorder diagnosis over developmental disorder diagnosis. 

I've dedicated my life now through whatever position I am working at the time to bettering our accessibility at those work places. As a UX Researcher, as a Web Designer, and even as a Customer Service rep, I have always tried to do what I can to ensure we're meeting people where they are, rather than forcing them to do work they shouldn't have to.

author: @restesdelune

That story about Olay‚Äôs dad traveling to attend a sermon had me dying! My Tias and Tios from Puerto Rico have done the same exact thing to attend sermons from YouTube ü§£

author: @gbabytiff
text: This was such an enlightening discussion (not to mention such a ki and I love Imani!!). As a Black woman who suffers from severe anxiety, Imani made me realize just how often I do everything in my power to make people more comfortable than I am. Most people don''t even recognize me has someone with anxiety because they see me as "high functioning" when the reality is, they don't see me doing the breathing exercises, running to the bathroom from nausea and finding any way to cope just to get through an event or a work day without bothering anyone. I would love more discussions on this topic, and I can't wait to look into some readings and follow more activists. :)

As a disabled veteran who has had issues with my back and neck since I was 20, I still feel like a bum when I say I live on disability. Especially since I cannnn do stuff but it causes a lot of pain. Realistically I can only do part time stuff before it‚Äôs impossible for me to stand. 
And it was a struggle to get the va funding that I currently have because legit every doctor was so fucking dismissive of my arthritis diagnosis at 20 years old from an injury while I was in the army. 
Even still at 30 I have to be pushy as fuck for my health issues.

author: @courtneylord
text:
Oh, y'all got into such an interesting facet of this topic at the end; I was thinking earlier about the role religion plays in the hyper-individualist nightmare in which we live, which is essentially that it fabricates moral "disabilities" that encourage us to marginalize certain groups. Our economy demands an underclass to motivate people to do more than they reasonably/healthily can, under threat of starvation/illness/exposure. Individuals are responsible for meeting our own basic needs, on a daily basis, for as long as we may live. In some cases, disabled people serve as the "example" for those who fail to lift their own weight, and people feel more or less comfortable viewing disabled people as a "societal burden"- as if we are incapable of meeting everyone's needs if disabled people contribute less. Well- the problem is that that's not true, and most of us are aware of that to some degree. Capitalism as we know it, aka multi-generational wealth recreating a thinly-veiled feudalism, rewards the owning class for taking the lion's share and making the rest of us fight for scraps.
Enter religion:
Given certain dogma, people feel morally superior to the people "tainted by sin," or sometimes it's truly just a patronizing "oh you poor [lost] lamb." Or the demons thing- not the first time I've heard someone dismiss their family member's condition as such. These justify a person's desire to revoke a person's humanity/autonomy, as those people are "not fit" to govern themselves, positioning the pious as a worthy authority. From there, people crusade against "degenerates," stripping away basic rights in exchange for votes, then praise the laymen for taking "personal responsibility." Empathy is antithetical to their goals, because they want to rule, not represent. Even if the faithful don't anticipate personally being at the top of the food chain, for them it's enough if they can ensure they aren't at the very bottom- and their party assures them that they're better than xyz minority- non-white, immigrants, disabled, queer, impoverished, etc. 
However, such gains are temporary and shortsighted. As long as we stay fighting each other, we are letting the people with the most power and destructive influence to get away with all kinds of inhumanity. Scarcity is manufactured in more ways than one, and some people have lost all faith in their ability to change the system, to the point that we sometimes run to the conveniences of modern living that are part of the problem, and the spiritual practices that distract us from it, like buying a lottery ticket with the last of your money, because we just might get a miracle. Wanting only what's best for ourselves, we leave every marginalized person in the dust, and disabled people are the first people we abandon.

author: @Who-en2vo
text: You both are such a blessing on this earth. I hit a wall recently and this is going to help me make it through. I‚Äôm chronically ill and disabled and trying to do more than I can sustainably, so I‚Äôm literally in bed listening to you two talking trying to accept I need to rest. (I‚Äôm my friend‚Äôs live in care attendant so his other care attendant is over visiting to help). It‚Äôs a humbling experience when your quadriplegic friend says sit your ass down and use your wheelchair around the house lol. I‚Äôm used to caring for everyone  else, either as an adultified child or professionally as a PCA/hospice aide/ service industry. I‚Äôm trying to listen earlier to my body saying sit your butt down before my body makes that decision for me. It‚Äôs a hard lesson to keep learning over and over that I have to take care of myself or else I‚Äôm not able to take care of anyone else, but also accept the situations in which I CAN receive care. Anyways that was a whole ramble but thank you thank you for putting words to things and helping to help me name things and release them, I‚Äôm sure many MANY people can say the same. I hope you both have some joyful and restful moments!

The other was around language; similar to you Olay, I thought that 'had autism' was the appropriate phrasing as opposed to 'autistic', as I Iikened it to how I was taught to discuss disability:  'people who live with a disability vs. disabled people'. Thanks for trying to level us up with your platform.

author: @anitrahooper5031
text:
Thank you for this beautiful discussion! I adore you both! As an adult in-home caregiver for my mother i can attest to the need for caregiver support & wages! It was rough, even & especially when she was on hospice. Within a month they were moving to discharge her because she wasn't dying fast enough. 

That meant I spent 2 of her last 5 months having to appeal twice & investigate other options for her care (she was bed bound). She had physical & mental/emotional disabilities, before her journey with dementia*. 

Additionally I am caring for my older brother who is neurodiverse, has CPTSD & other emotional disabilities, along with some physical. Yet he is not seen as disabled enough to recieve benefits. We are hoing throuhh the hoops, but it is hard. 

Not to mention my own aging body & disabilities (mostly invisible), while ensuring a stable life for my partner & our son. 

It scares me to think of what might happen to my brother (Black male who has reactions like a 12-16 year old boy with conflict avoidance). I fear for any interactions with police or anyone else who thinks he's a threat just because of how he looks (disheveled by society standards).

Again, i am so pleased that you two have come together & look forward to more collaborative adventures & the changes we can all make for those who are not seen, heard, or cared for with the respect every human deserves! 

I love you üíúüôåüèæüåà‚úäüèæüíú

author: @Robstafarian
text: I had one of those "get taken to a church" moments with some of my extended relatives.  The difference is that it was their far-right, fundamentalist, evangelical church: they set it up such that I was called to the stage by name.  I expect that is a unique version of feeling exploited by people who should be trustworthy.

author: @tangimeme
text: This was such a great interview! Serious stuff, but still had me giggling a lot üòÜ I've been thinking about this topic a ton lately and it's a relief to hear people talk about it more. I watched this right after watching the new Contra Tangent on her Patreon about granola fascism and they basically work as companion videos the way they fit together. It has been tough trying to get my mum to just accept that I'm sick and unable to live the life she wanted for me because of that. I'm figuring out how to be okay with it, but she's into a ton of pseudo-medicine and new-agey evangelical stuff so believes in the law of attraction etc. It makes it so she can't help but frame my health problems as a failure on my part, like, something I've been doing wrong that would get better if I just tried and believed harder. She's always looking for something to blame be it literal demons, me bringing it on myself through negative thoughts, my resistance to go to quacks instead of doctors, or my eating habits. It's sad 'cause it stresses her out and creates tension between us, but I don't know how to get her to see the reality and accept it because her whole worldview is built around magical, unfalsifiable beliefs üòÖ It worries me that if genuinely caring parents are willing to see their kids as the cause of their own illnesses and disabilities, it's gonna be an uphill battle to get strangers to humanise us more üò¨ That said, I'm so glad people like Imani and Olay are making people more aware of this stuff so we have a better chance of changing minds for the better! ‚ù§ It gives me hope and motivation, so I really hope we get to see Imani again on the pod üòç She's so funny and has regular guest/co-host energy haha

author: @leelindsay5618
text: With "auto-immune" diseases, the medical community make me question if scurvy would be labeled as auto-immune diease these days versus just a key mineral deficiency. I'm not all auto-immune are just something simple, but finding out daily magnesium supplements cause folks with  fibromialgia to become symptom free after a month or two as one example really makes me wonder.
